stream_context.summary: Kaze spends most of the session importing and debugging Biobak’s new, highly-optimized Mario model, while concept-sketching a Portal-style light bridge and arcade button for the casino/arcade area. The work veers deep into N64 combiner logic, palette tricks, and hardware limits, with side discussions about cache-level CPU hacks and upcoming sponsorships.

development_findings.summary: New Mario model from Biobak reduces triangles from 639 to 595 and cuts TMEM usage ~40 %. Textures converted to lower-bit formats (I4/CI8), vertex colors cleaned, eyebrows recolored, shoes given shine, and overall folds added.
development_findings.quote: This model has 170 triangles less than 64 Mario… and smaller textures than the original Mario model.

development_findings.summary: Importer / Fast64 inaccuracies forced Kaze to hand-tune combine modes to keep anti-aliasing while adding per-pixel lighting. Final fix: convert the cap ‘M’ to an indexed palette texture and HSV-shift all 16 colors at runtime.
development_findings.quote: I settled on a different solution; this one is possible, unlike the other solution which is not.

development_findings.summary: Button lighting originally ‘glowed’ because lighting influence was halved; Kaze rewrote the combine (double shade color, one-cycle) to make them appear reflective rather than emissive.
development_findings.quote: They should no longer be glowing, but they should be shiny.

development_findings.summary: Planned light bridge: fully transparent until switch pressed, then turns solid, changes color, and eventually fades; may use Layer 4 or dither to avoid ambiguous visuals.
development_findings.quote: There needs to be a warning that the bridge is gonna disappear, so we can't go straight to alpha.

development_findings.summary: Exploring three low-level cache hacks: 1) read i-cache history in idle thread to prefetch the next task; 2) ‘hit & invalidate’ only likely RAM addresses when scheduling RCP tasks; 3) reserve dirty exclusive cache lines for OS routines so they never touch main RAM.
development_findings.quote: Most of the cool shit isn't implemented yet… but these ideas should reduce memory throughput.

development_findings.summary: Discovered hardware limit: too many concurrent dynamic lights cause color shifts (yellow crystals appeared green). Suspects N64 supports only ~5 lights per model; will test on real hardware.
development_findings.quote: I think I'm just being hit by so many crystals that we can't perceive this one here.

context_findings.summary: Kaze prefers mechanics that fit an ‘arcade vibe’ over perfectly recreating classic arcade mini-games, aiming for cohesion with SM64’s playstyle.
context_findings.quote: I don't want too many game games; I want it all more to have the arcade vibe.

context_findings.summary: Shows pride in extreme technical efficiency—‘lower poly, smaller textures, better look’ mantra—and views beating N64 limits as an artistic goal.
context_findings.quote: Game studios would never understand… they'll be like just use a 32×32 please.

context_findings.summary: Humorously weighs sponsorships (Manscaped, even a dildo company) but is wary of brand fit.
context_findings.quote: So far I've said no, however, we are probably getting a Manscaped sponsorship.

context_findings.summary: Ends stream early for a visit with Zeina’s parents, suggesting deliberate work-life boundaries.
context_findings.quote: Me and Zeina have an appointment today at her parents'.

biobak.summary: Delivered the new Mario model and supplied a detailed change-log (TMEM cuts, texture downsizing, sideburn redesign, wing smoothing).
biobak.quote: 39 % reduction TMEM time… makes the old Mario model look like a beta model.

biobak.summary: Gave real-time feedback (button lighting, butt crease, preview materials) and agreed to minor compromises (two-cycle shaders, subtle crease).
biobak.quote: Too bad for them… Mario’s ass got nerfed.

zeina.summary: Suggested grayscale-first workflow for gradient colors; not fully explored.
zeina.quote: If you have an idea on how to get the colors there in grayscale, then sure, go for it.

zeina.summary: Personal context: Kaze paused development to attend an appointment with her family.
zeina.quote: I'll see you later. Bye bye!

key_stories.title: Mario Model Overhaul
key_stories.summary: The outdated player model was memory-heavy and visually dated. Biobak delivered a lean replacement; Kaze fought N64 combiner quirks, palette limits, and lighting to make it shine.
key_stories.challenge: Modernizing Mario without exceeding N64 triangle or TMEM budgets.
key_stories.process: Imported model, inspected every submesh, rewired combine modes, converted textures, added palette tricks, re-balanced lighting, and even drew a subtle butt crease.
key_stories.outcome: Finished model looks better, runs cheaper, and will headline the next dev video.
key_stories.key_quote: This looks so insanely good… my first 1 million-view video that Nintendo doesn't take down.

key_stories.title: The Impossible Cap ‘M’
key_stories.summary: Kaze tried to keep anti-aliasing while shading the cap logo but hit hardware limits. After multiple failed combine setups, he pivoted to an indexed palette and runtime HSV shifts.
key_stories.challenge: Combine cycles couldn’t handle both per-pixel lighting and edge AA on an RGBA16 logo.
key_stories.process: Experimented with force-blend, coverage hacks, two-cycle modes; finally rebuilt the texture as I4 and wrote C code to recolor all 16 palette entries.
key_stories.outcome: Logo now lights correctly and supports dynamic cap colors without extra cycles.
key_stories.key_quote: We did it, guys. It's over.
